section_01.section_summary: The author's interest in science was sparked by reading Tyndall's "Discourse on The Scientific Use of the Imagination" and was further developed by reading Herbert Spencer's works, particularly his essay "Progress: its Law and Cause". Spencer's philosophy of evolution, which describes the transformation of the simple into the complex through successive differentiations, had a profound impact on the author. The author notes that Spencer's idea of differentiation as the cardinal law of evolution implies a universal cause, and that every active force produces more than one change. Spencer's work, although sometimes narrow in focus, made significant contributions to biology, psychology, sociology, and ethics, and his ideas have been widely assimilated into modern scientific thought. The author believes that Spencer's early essay contains the germ of his best teachings and that his method was most effectively employed in interpreting phenomena from a biological or quasi-biological point of view.

section_02.section_summary: In his later years, Spencer was disheartened to see that his social and political doctrines were not widely accepted by a new generation of thinkers. Despite this, his philosophy of life and mind remains a significant contribution to history. Spencer's philosophy emphasizes the universality of law and evolution, and he believed that all phenomena can be explained in terms of matter, motion, and force. His philosophy is all-inclusive, encompassing biology, psychology, sociology, and ethics as part of the larger mechanical drama of evolution. Ultimately, Spencer's philosophy acknowledges the mystery of existence, but seeks to explain everything in terms of the interrelationship between matter and mind.
